intro: Recreational scuba diving and freediving requires good physical and mental health. There are a few medical conditions which can be hazardous while diving, listed below. Those who have, or are predisposed to, any of these conditions, should be evaluated by a physician. This Diver Medical Participant Questionnaire provides a basis to determine if you should seek out that evaluation. If you have any concerns about your diving fitness not represented on this form, consult with your physician before diving. If you are feeling ill, avoid diving. If you think you may have a contagious disease, protect yourself and others by not participating in dive training and/or dive activities. References to “diving” on this form encompass both recreational scuba diving and freediving. This form is principally designed as an initial medical screen for new divers, but is also appropriate for divers taking continuing education. For your safety, and that of others who may dive with you, answer all questions honestly.
final_text:
If you answered NO to all 10 questions above, a medical evaluation is not required. Please read and agree to the participant statement below by signing and dating it.
Participant Statement: I have answered all questions honestly, and understand that I accept responsibility for any consequences resulting from any questions I may have answered inaccurately or for my failure to disclose any existing or past health conditions.
* If you answered YES to questions 3, 5 or 10 above OR to any of the I HAVE/HAD questions, please read and agree to the statement above by signing it AND take all this form (Participant Questionnaire and the Physician’s Evaluation Form) to your physician for a medical evaluation. Participation in a diving course requires your physician’s approval.

safe.title: Standard Safe Diving Practices Statement of Understanding
safe.intro: This statement informs you of the established practices for safe scuba diving and freediving. These practices are provided for your acknowledgment and agreement, and they are intended to enhance your comfort and safety while diving. It is mandatory that you sign this statement as proof that you are aware of these safe diving practices. Please read and discuss the statement before signing it. If you are a minor, the form must also be signed by a parent or guardian.
safe.text:
understand that as a diver I must:

1. Maintain good physical and mental condition for diving. Avoid diving under the influence of alcohol or dangerous drugs. Maintain my diving skills and strive to improve them through continued education and review them in controlled conditions after periods of diving inactivity, and consult my course materials to stay up-to-date and recall important information.

2. Be familiar with my dive sites. If not, receive a formal orientation from a competent local source. If dive conditions are worse than those in which I have experience, postpone the dive or choose an alternative site with better conditions. Participate only in diving activities that are within my training and experience. Do not participate in cave or technical diving unless specifically trained for such activities.

3. Use complete, well-maintained, reliable equipment that I am familiar with, and inspect it for proper fit and operation before each dive. Have a buoyancy control device, low-pressure inflation system, submersible pressure gauge, alternate air source, and a dive planning/control device (dive computer, RDP/dive tables, whichever I am trained to use) when scuba diving. Refuse to allow uncertified divers to use my equipment.

4. Listen carefully to dive briefings and instructions and follow the advice of those supervising my diving activities. Recognize that additional training is recommended for participation in specialized diving activities, in different geographic areas, and after periods of inactivity exceeding six months.

5. Observe the buddy system on every dive. Plan dives (including communication, separation, and emergency procedures) with my buddy.

6. Master dive planning (use of dive computer and dive tables). Make all dives as no-decompression dives and allow for a safety margin. Have a means to monitor depth and time underwater. Limit maximum depth according to my training and experience. Ascend at a rate no faster than 18 meters/60 feet per minute. Be a SAFE diver—ascend slowly from every dive. Perform a safety stop as an additional precaution, usually at 5 meters/15 feet for three minutes or more.

7. Maintain proper buoyancy. Adjust weights at the surface for neutral buoyancy without air in my buoyancy control device. Maintain neutral buoyancy underwater. Be able to float and rest at the surface. Keep weights quick-releasable and establish buoyancy in case of a problem while diving. Carry at least one surface signaling device (such as a signaling tube, whistle, mirror).

8. Breathe properly while diving. Never hold my breath or stop breathing when breathing compressed air, and avoid excessive hyperventilation when breath-hold diving. Avoid overexertion while entering and being underwater, and dive within my limitations.

9. Use a boat, float, or other surface support station whenever feasible.

10. Know and obey local diving laws and regulations, including fishing and hunting laws and dive flag legislation.

I understand the importance and purpose of these established practices. I acknowledge that they are for my own safety and well-being, and that failure to adhere to them may expose me to diving risks.
